Description.val:
This line item funds modifications to the Joint Primary Aircraft Training System (JPATS).  JPATS is a joint, United States Air Force led, acquisition program.  Principal JPATS mission is primary training for entry-level student pilots, associated instructor pilots, and primary/intermediate training for United States Navy Naval Flight Officers.  JPATS includes the T-6 Texan II, aircraft and Ground Based Training Devices (GBTS) which is a stepped tandem seat, commercially derived aircraft powered by a single turboprop engine.  

The overall goal of modifications budgeted is to correct discrepancies, deficiencies and obsolescence discovered after the delivery of the aircraft and to commence upgrades to avionic systems for FAA compliance.  Efforts include modifications to address safety, reliability, maintainability, obsolescence and Diminishing Manufacturing Source (DMSMS) requirements. Modifications, particularly to avionics systems, may also be driven by new Cyber Security requirements.

Current (FY 2019) Navy T-6 inventory is 294 aircraft (43 T-6A and 251 T-6B aircraft) with aircraft service life thru 2035.  The Department of the Navy received delivery of final production Aircraft in 2016. Navy JPATS inventory includes 34 Ground Based Trainer System (GBTS) units (7 T-6A and 27 T-6B representative systems).

Justification.val: Funding in FY 2021 is required for Physiological Episode Mitigation, avionics/airframe/propulsion upgrade kits, and to provide support for Joint Primary Aircraft Training System retrofits.

Name.val: 2.1.3) Onboard Oxygen Generating System - Concentrator - Organic

Name.@footnote: 2.2.1) Non-recurring Engineering (NRE): FY 2020 NRE was decreased compared to FY 2019 budget request due to realigning NRE to new OSIPs (007-20, 008-20, and 009-20)

Description.val:
This Operational Safety Improvement Program (OSIP) funds correction of deficiencies discovered during test and evaluation or operational use to the entire airframe, its components and subassemblies, avionics, related Peculiar Support Equipment, and Ground Based Training Systems.  

This OSIP includes modifications to address safety, reliability, maintainability, obsolescence, and Diminishing Manufacturing Source (DMSMS) requirements.  Modifications, particularly to avionic systems, may also be driven by new Cyber Security requirements.   

Correction of Deficiencies Engineering Change Proposals (ECPs) include:  Airframe Structural/Sub-systems; Auto Ignition Relay; Avionics Obsolescence; Onboard Oxygen Generating System; Avionics Hardware/Software Modifications; System Safety Avionics; Controlled Flight Into Terrain Prevention and Crash Survivable Cockpit Voice Recorder; and Safe Arm Handle.  

DEVELOPMENT STATUS/MAJOR DEVELOPMENT MILESTONES: Beginning in FY 2020 budget request JPATS CORRECTION OF DEFICIENCIES (OSIP 011-04) has been broken out between OSIPs Physiological Episodes (OSIP 007-20), Airframe/Propulsion (008-20), and Avionics (009-20), to better align with the program.

Name.@footnote: 2.6) Other Support:  Automated Dependent Surveillance Broadcast Out modifications that are specific to T-6B aircraft.  Support includes, contracting support and Joint Support costs to the United States Air Force.  Navy also provides support to Joint program acquisition efforts for T-6A aircraft.

ImplementationMethodName.val: Contractor Field Mods:: Installation Name: Install Aircraft Retrofit Kits & GBTS - T-6B

1.1.2) GBTS Kits (T-6A): Due to different unit costs for the aircraft retrofit and Ground Based Training System (GBTS) kits, a separate GBTS kit line was added to the P3A to price out costs individually.

Description.val:
This Operational Safety Improvement Program (OSIP) funds upgrades to avionic systems necessary for compliance with Federal Aviation Administration 28 May 2010 release DoT/FAA, 14 CFR Part 91: Automated Dependent Surveillance Broadcast (ADS-B) Out performance requirements to support Air Traffic Control (ATC) service final rule. This mandate stipulates that all aircraft required to have unrestricted access to operate in Classes A, B, and C airspace, certain Class E airspace, and other specified airspace requiring ADS-B Out, must be in compliance with this regulation by January 1, 2020. 

DEVELOPMENT STATUS/MAJOR DEVELOPMENT MILESTONES:  System development efforts for this update commenced in FY 2015, with hardware development costs reflected in R-1 Line #90.  Non-recurring engineering and support efforts for Engineering Change Proposal development and implementation has commenced.

Name.@footnote: 2.1.1) Onboard Oxygen Generating System - Concentrator: Effort migrated from OSIP 011-04. Effort was executed from OSIP 011-04 in FY2018 and FY2019. Installation will be provided by our Contractor Logistics Service provider, installation is under 25 hours so no installation funding is required. The new Type-0106A Oxygen Concentrator is required to modernize the T-6 OBOGS system and reduce PE events.  The USAF has decided not to purchase this model concentrator and this will increase the unit cost.  In addition, there are currently 100 Type-0106 models in service/inventory that will require funding for material modifications to upgrade to the Type-0106A standard.  Additional Field Downloadable Data (FDD) Test Sets may also be purchased to support the Type-0106A in the field.

2.1.2 OBOGS Concentrator Next Generation - Incorporates the latest understanding of MIL-STD requirements.  Utilizes advanced electronic controls with the latest software development. It's a field maintainable Line Replaceable Unit (LRU) design, built in troubleshooting, and allows internal data recording of performance and exporting to a future onboard crash survivable recorder.  Twelve prototypes are currently in testing.  Planned production to begin in 3Q2020, and delivery in 1Q2021.
2.2.1 Non-Recurring Engineering will engineer, test and evaluate a myriad of OBOGS initiatives to address ongoing T-6 aircrew PE concerns.

Description.val:
This Operational Safety and Improvement Program (OSIP) funds modifications to the T-6 training system to address aircrew physiological episodes (PE).  PEs have been increasing in number since formal reporting commenced in 2012.  All aircraft systems that contribute to aircrew life support can be causal factors in physiological events.  This includes the Onboard Oxygen Generating System (OBOGS) and all associated piping, valves, and monitors, the Environmental Control System (ECS), engine bleed air delivered to the OBOGS and ECS piping, and aircrew alerting systems to warn of failures.  Modifications to the aircraft will focus on addressing the highest likelihood causal factors for PEs.  These include a new next generation oxygen concentrator, new discrete pressure alerting, OBOGS component improvements to reduce pressure loss, ECS improvements to prevent rapid cockpit decompression, cabin altitude monitoring and alerting, and air quality monitoring and filtration. PE Mitigation efforts prior to FY 2020 were funded out of OSIP 011-04 Corrections of Deficiencies.  

DEVELOPMENT STATUS/MAJOR DEVELOPMENT MILESTONES: FY 2020 and out funds provide for non-recurring engineering, kit procurement, and installation in support of T-6 physiological episode mitigation.

Name.@footnote: 1.1.1) Canopy Fracturing Initiation System (CFIS) - Ballistic previously procured and installed under OSIP 011-04.  Due to aircraft availability remaining retrofit kits will not be procured to FY2021.

Description.val:
This Operational Safety Improvement Program (OSIP) funds airframe, prevention modifications and propulsion discovered during test and evaluation or operational use to the entire airframe, its components and subassemblies, related Peculiar Support Equipment, and Ground Based Training Systems.  

This OSIP includes modifications to address safety, reliability, maintainability, obsolescence, and Diminishing Manufacturing Source (DMSMS) requirements.  Modifications, particularly to the airframe, may also be driven by propulsion requirements.   

Airframe/Propulsion Engineering Change Proposals (ECPs) include:  Airframe Structural/Sub-systems modifications; Auto Ignition Relay; Landing Gear Control Handle redesign; and future propulsion modifications.

DEVELOPMENT STATUS/MAJOR DEVELOPMENT MILESTONES:  Continued service life extension of aircraft by continuing incorporation of Engineering Change Proposals.

ImplementationMethodName.val: Contractor Field Modification:: Installation Name: Crash Survivable Cockpit Recorder

Name.@footnote: 2.1.5) Safety System Compliance GBTS - Quantity Includes GBTS for T-6A and T-6B

2.1.6) Avionics Obsolescence: Modifications to the avionics will be required to upgrade the electronic flight instrument displays, Altitude and Heading Reference (AHRS) controller, Midair Collision Avoidance, Military Flight Operations Quality Assurance (MFOQA) and backup flight instruments and those avionic components associated with the affected aircraft systems to include associated software updates. Previously budgeted under OSIP 011-04.
2.2.1 increase in FY21 is due to the start of 2.1.2) Controlled Flight Into Terrain Avoidance and  2.1.4) and  Crash Survivable Cockpit Recorder.   To ensure performance of production components.

Description.val:
This Operational Safety Improvement Program (OSIP) funds avionics upgrades discovered during test and evaluation or operational use to the entire avionics, its components and subassemblies, related Peculiar Support Equipment, and Ground Based Training Systems.  

This OSIP includes modifications to address safety, reliability, maintainability, obsolescence, and Diminishing Manufacturing Source (DMSMS) requirements.  Modifications, particularly to avionic systems, may also be driven by new Cyber Security requirements.   

Avionics Engineering Change Proposals (ECPs) include:  Auto Ignition Relay; Avionics Hardware/Software Modifications; System Safety Avionics; Controlled Flight Into Terrain Prevention and Crash Survivable Cockpit Voice Recorder.  

DEVELOPMENT STATUS/MAJOR DEVELOPMENT MILESTONES: Continued avionics extension by continuing incorporation of Engineering Change Proposals.
